title: Part b. [0–7]
stimulusHtml:
7 points (i. 2 points; ii. 3 points; iii. 2 points)

i. 2 points

1 point: For indicating a correct pair of quantities to graph

1 point: For a correct explanation

Method 1: Graph quantities such as D versus t2 or v versus t. Such graphs are linear, and the slope will yield the acceleration.

Method 2: Graph quantities such as a versus t or a versus x, using the equation from part a. to determine the accelerations. Such graphs are linear, and the a intercept will yield the acceleration.

Method 3: Graph D versus t, which is parabolic. The equation that describes the best fit curve is quadratic, and the second derivative is the acceleration.

ii. 3 points

One example of a correct graph

1 point: For using data consistent with the answer to b.i.

1 point: For plotting the data correctly, including labeling the axes and their scales

1 point: For constructing a best fit line or curve, depending on the data graphed

iii. 2 points

1 point: For using points from the best fit line, not data points

1 point: For correctly determining the acceleration, including correct units and explicitly showing how the points yield the answer
For example, using the graph shown

a=2( slope )=2( 2.0m−0.5m 1.97 s 2 −0.5 s 2 )=2( 1.5m 1.47 s 2 )=2.04m/ s 2 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaGaamyyaiabg2 da9iaaikdadaqadaqaaiaadohacaWGSbGaam4BaiaadchacaWGLbaa caGLOaGaayzkaaGaeyypa0JaaGOmamaabmaabaWaaSaaaeaacaaIYa GaaiOlaiaaicdacaWGTbGaeyOeI0IaaGimaiaac6cacaaI1aGaamyB aaqaaiaaigdacaGGUaGaaGyoaiaaiEdacaWGZbWaaWbaaSqabeaaca aIYaaaaOGaeyOeI0IaaGimaiaac6cacaaI1aGaam4CamaaCaaaleqa baGaaGOmaaaaaaaakiaawIcacaGLPaaacqGH9aqpcaaIYaWaaeWaae aadaWcaaqaaiaaigdacaGGUaGaaGynaiaad2gaaeaacaaIXaGaaiOl aiaaisdacaaI3aGaam4CamaaCaaaleqabaGaaGOmaaaaaaaakiaawI cacaGLPaaacqGH9aqpcaaIYaGaaiOlaiaaicdacaaI0aGaamyBaiaa c+cacaWGZbWaaWbaaSqabeaacaaIYaaaaaaa@6603@

title: Part d. [0–2]
stimulusHtml:
2 points

1 point: For a reasonable analysis of the answer to part c. that explicitly indicates either the effective mass or radius is greater than given in the initial paragraph of the question, or the experimental acceleration obtained in b.iii. is greater than it would be without experimental error

1 point: For a possible physical reason for the discrepant value

Examples:

The string was wrapped around the pulley several times, causing the effective radius at which the torque acted to be larger than the radius of the pulley used in the calculation

The string slipped on the pulley, allowing the block to accelerate faster than it would have otherwise, resulting in a smaller experimental moment of inertia

Note: Friction is not a correct answer, since the presence of friction would make the experimental value of the moment of inertia too large.
